div.head: Names and Dates
div.p: This chapter describes a module which may be used for the encoding of names (names of persons or corporations/organizations) or descriptive phrases for styles, periods or geographical indications. In section xy Names, Numbers, Dates, Abbreviations, and Addresses it was noted that the elements provided in the core module allow an encoder to specify that a given text segment is a proper noun. The elements provided by the present module allow the encoder to supply a detailed sub-structure for such proper nouns, and to distinguish explicitly between persons and organizations, and between stylistic, periodical or geographical indications.

The chapter begins by discussing the elements provided for the encoding of names (name) and dates (date) in general, up to more specifical elements like corporate names (corpName), geographical names (geogName), period names (periodName), personal names (persName) and style names (styleName). In general it is recommended to use standardised spelling forms of proper nouns conforming to standards and to record the names and web-accessible locations of used controlled vocabularies. Especially for geographical, organizational and personal names there are several authority files, such as the Gemeinsame Normdatei (GND), the Library of Congress Authorities, the Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names (TGN) or the MARC code list for relators. Recommendations on which standards could be used can be found in the descriptions of the individual elements.

div.head: Overview of the namesDates module
div.p: The module described in this chapter makes available the following components:

div.head: Elements
div.p: Basic Elements and Data Structures of the namesDates module are:

div.head: name
div.p: The name element contains the name of an entity that is difficult to tag more specifically as a corpName, geogName, persName, or title. In section xy Names, Numbers, Dates, Abbreviations, and Addresses it was noted that the name element may be used in place of the more specific elements when it is not known what kind of name is being described or when a high degree of precision is not necessary. For example, the name element might be used when it is not clear whether the name "Bach" refers to a person or a geographic feature. When name parts are needed, use name sub-elements. The recommended values for the type attribute are: pers, corp, place, process. The date sub-element is available within name in order to record any dates, associated with the name, i.e. creation and dissolution in the case of a corporate entity or place. The name of the list from which a controlled value is taken, such as the Library of Congress Name Authority File (LCNAF), may be recorded using the authority attribute.

Examples for the use of the name element are:
Henry VIII, King of England
The Beatles
Bach

div.head: date
div.p:
The element date contains a date in any format, including a date range, which may be expressed either as textual content, e.g., March 1-21, 1812, or using date sub-elements, possibly combined with text, e.g., March 1, 1812 - March 21, 1812. The latter form is useful when the starting and ending points of the date range require qualification. The date element may occur within a set of elements. To specify the given data the following attributes can be used:
calendar: indicates the system or calendar to which a date belongs, for example, Gregorian, Julian, Roman, Mosaic, Revolutionary, Islamic, etc.
cert: signifies the degree of certainty or precision associated with a feature (high, medium, low, unknown)
enddate: contains the end point of a date range
notafter: contains an upper boundary for an uncertain date
notbefore: contains a lower boundary for an uncertain date
reg: gives the value of a date in standard ISO form.
startdate: contains the starting point of a date range

div.head: corpName
div.p: Corporate names are non-personal names which refer to structured bodies of one or more persons that act as a single entity. Typical examples include associations, businesses, projects or institutions (e.g. 'the Royal College of Music' or 'the BBC'), but also racial or ethnic groupings or political factions where these are regarded as forming a single agency. Organization names typically include some type of indicator or pattern or words that help identify them as non-personal names.

The corpName element is particularly used within the header of an MEI document. It might be enclosed in the respStmt element (example 1)
Library of Congress
or could be used whereever it is necessary to mark up a corporate name, for example if a corporation is responsible for a certain event in the history of a musical work (example 2)
When name parts are needed, they could be encoded in corpName sub-elements, for example: Federal Research Division, Library of Congress

CorpName elements as well as corpName sub-elements might also be completed with address-elements for entering postal addresses of organizations within several addrLine elements. German Research Foundation
Kennedyallee 40 53175 Bonn Germany

Exact designations of corporate names can be taken from a controlled vocabulary, such as the Gemeinsame Normdatei (GND). If a controlled value is used, the list, from which it is taken should be recorded. In this case the following attributes are particularly relevant:
authority: to record the list from which a controlled value is taken,
authURI (authority URI): to record the web-accessible location of the controlled vocabulary from which the value is taken,
dbkey (database key): to record a value which serves as a primary key in an external database.

div.head: geogName
div.p: Geographical names are proper noun designations for places (e.g. Baltimore, Maryland), natural features (e.g. Black Forest) or political jurisdictions (e.g. Quartier Latin, Paris). Like other proper nouns or noun phrases used as names, they can simply be marked up with the geogName element.
The element can be used, e.g., to label geographical names in titles: Bohemian folk songs or Music in the German Democratic Republic
Name sub-parts may be encoded in geogName sub-elements. For example: Baltimore, Maryland

To enable a localization of an organization or to specify names of places with identical names it is recommendable to use a controlled vocabulary for names of places and countries. In this case the following attributes are particularly relevant:
authority: to record the list from which a controlled value is taken, e.g. the Thesaurus of Geographic Names (TGN),
authURI (authority URI): to record the web-accessible location of the controlled vocabulary from which the value is taken,
dbkey (database key): to record a value which serves as a primary key in an external database.

The encoder may use these attributes in combination. In case of the city Frankfurt, for example, a clarification whether Frankfurt am Main or Frankfurt an der Oder is meant, can be achieved by indicating the ID of the TGN entry.
Frankfurt am Main: Frankfurt
Frankfurt an der Oder: Frankfurt

The names of places given within addresses could be marked up with geogName elements as well, for example: German Research Foundation
Kennedyallee 40 53175 Bonn Germany

div.head: periodName
div.p: PeriodNames are names which describe a particular period of time, which were characterized by obvious similarities in style, for example 'Baroque' or '3rd Style Period'. Baroque

Each epochal term is to be seen as problematic, as it creates the impression that various styles replace each other directly and completely. This creates a number of differentiation issues, as there had indeed been simultaneous stylistic tendencies with little in common (and even often contradictory).

The date sub-element is available within periodName in order to record any dates, associated with the periodName, i.e. the startdate and the enddate of a certain epoch:
Baroque . The startdate and the enddate of a certain period may also be recorded by using the startdate and enddate attributes. Baroque .

If a controlled value is used, the list, from which it is taken should be recorded. In this case the following attributes are particularly relevant:
authority: to record the list from which a controlled value is taken,
authURI (authority URI): to record the web-accessible location of the controlled vocabulary from which the value is taken,
dbkey (database key): to record a value which serves as a primary key in an external database.

div.head: persName
div.p: Personal names within an MEI-Doument could simply be marked up with the persName element which contains a propernoun or proper-noun phrase referring to an individual person. Personal names consist of several components, like forenames and surnames, but also other components like inherited or life-time titles of nobility, honorific or academic prefixes, military ranks or traditional descriptive phrases. It is not possible to mark up each of these components separately in MEI.

The persName element is often enclosed in the respStmt element which may occur within titleStmt, pubStmt, seriesStmt and change. A typical environment of the persName element would look like this:
Im wunderschönen Monat Mai
Robert Schumann

Apart from the composer or originator of a musical work, there could be a lot of other persons being involved into the genesis of a musical work, like librettists, lyricists, arrangers, editors, transcripers, printers, publishers etc. The special roles of these persons may be marked up with the role attribute. For example: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart or Heinrich Heine The Marc code list for relators offers a variety of controlled terms on this concern.

It is recommended to record personal names by using a standard for personal names, such as the Gemeinsame Normdatei (GND) or the Library of Congress Name Authorities. The name of the list as well as the web-accessible location from which a controlled value is taken may be recorded using the authority and the authURI attribute. To record a value which serves as a primary key in an external database, the dbkey attribute may be used.
Ideally, the three attributes are used in combination. For example: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

Any data according to a person can be marked up by using the date sub-element. However, life data should not be marked up separately when taking a controlled value, as information relating to the biography of a person should be recorded in the linked database.

div.head: styleName
div.p: Music can be devided into different genres, forms and styles. The term style denotes a mode of expression or more particularly the manner in which a work of art is executed. "In the discussion of music, which is orientated towards relationships rather than meanings, the term raises special difficulties; it may be used to denote music characterized of an individual composer, of a period, of a geographical area or centre, or of a society or social function. For the aesthetician style concerns surface or appearance, though in music appearance and essence are ultimately inseparable. For the historian a style is a distinguishing and ordering concept, both consistent of and denoting generalities; he or she groups examples of music according to similarities between them." (Source: Grove Music Online, Article: Style, request date: 27.04.2012) Musical styles have to be distinguished from musical genres. The transitions are, however, fluent. The styleName element should not be confused with the periodName element (see above).

StyleNames can be simply marked up with the styleName element, for example: bebop . It may be, e.g., used for recording a stylename within a title: La voix du bebop , or to record a style of a certain epoch by using the styleName sub-element: Moderne Jazz

If a controlled value is used, the list, from which it is taken should be recorded. In this case the following attributes are particularly relevant:
authority: to record the list from which a controlled value is taken,
authURI (authority URI): to record the web-accessible location of the controlled vocabulary from which the value is taken,
dbkey (database key): to record a value which serves as a primary key in an external database.

div.head: Attribute Classes
div.p: No attribute classes are defined in this module.
